explanation: Kepler's three laws describe planetary motion around the Sun: orbits are ellipses with the Sun at one focus, planets sweep equal areas in equal times, and the square of orbital period is proportional to the cube of the semi-major axis. These empirical laws provided the foundation for Newton's law of gravitation and remain fundamental to celestial mechanics and orbital dynamics.

equations_assumptions.text: The central body (Sun) is much more massive than the orbiting body (planet).
Only gravitational forces act between the bodies (two-body problem).
The gravitational force follows an inverse square law.
The orbiting bodies can be treated as point masses.

derivation_assumptions.text: Newton's law of gravitation applies with an inverse square force law.
Angular momentum is conserved due to the central nature of the gravitational force.
The orbit is a closed ellipse with the central body at one focus.
Energy conservation applies throughout the orbital motion.

derivation_explanation.text: Start with Newton's law of gravitation as the central force.
Angular momentum is conserved because the gravitational force is central.

Solve for angular velocity in terms of angular momentum and radius.
The area element swept in time dt is a sector of angle dθ.
Calculate the rate of area sweeping using the chain rule.
Substitute angular velocity to show area rate is constant (Kepler's 2nd law).
Write the total energy as kinetic plus potential energy.
For elliptical orbits, total energy is related to the semi-major axis.
Introduce the substitution u = 1/r to linearize the orbital equation.
Derive the differential equation for u(θ) from the force law.
Solve the differential equation to get the general solution.
Convert back to r(θ) to get the orbit equation.
Identify the relationship between orbital parameters and angular momentum.
Obtain Kepler's first law: the orbit is an ellipse with the Sun at one focus.
Calculate the total area of the ellipse using semi-major and semi-minor axes.
The period is the total area divided by the constant area rate.
Use the relationship between angular momentum and orbital parameters.
Derive Kepler's third law relating period squared to semi-major axis cubed.
